It is characterized by its distinctive, pendulous, and often fleshy fruits that resemble small testes, giving it its unusual common name. The plant is native to certain regions of Africa and thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. Its leaves are typically alternate, simple, and have a waxy texture, while its flowers are inconspicuous and clustered in cyathia. Due to its peculiar appearance, it is often cultivated as an ornamental plant in botanical gardens and private collections.
